Title.evidence: In this two-centre randomized controlled trial

Trial_Design.evidence: In this two-centre randomized controlled trial

Participants.evidence: patients undergoing major abdominal surgery anticipated to experience prolonged hyperglycemia

Intervention.evidence: we contrasted subcutaneous FCL with UC glucose management

Objective.evidence: To assess the efficacy and safety of fully closed-loop (FCL) compared with usual care (UC) glucose control

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the proportion of time with sensor glucose values in a target range of 5.6 to 10.0 mmol/L.

Blinding.evidence: Glucose control was assessed using continuous glucose monitoring (masked in the UC group).

Number_Randomised.evidence: Thirty-seven surgical patients (54% pancreas, 22% liver, 19% upper gastrointestinal, 5% lower gastrointestinal), of whom 18 received FCL and 19 UC glucose management

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean ± SD percentage time with sensor glucose in the target range was 80.1% ± 10.0% in the FCL and 53.7% ± 19.7% in the UC group ( P < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: No study-related serious adverse events occurred.
